speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.1: COVID Mask Policy - The board will discuss the district’s COVID-19 health protocols, specifically whether students should be required to wear masks while in classrooms. This policy would apply during the regular school day, with exceptions for lunch and designated mask-break periods. The goal is to balance student safety with comfort and learning effectiveness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thanks, Graham. I think it's important we hear from our teachers and students first—what do they feel safe doing? Maybe we could start by hearing how many kids actually *want* to wear masks right now?

speaker: kateacuff
content: David, I think maybe what we need is an anonymous survey of our staff and our students to get some real-time information on where they stand.

speaker: judyle
content: Thank you, Kate. I agree—we definitely need that data. But I wonder, how soon could we get results back from something like that? And who exactly would we want to include?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Judi, good point—I’d love to know how quickly we could gather those results. Should we involve parents too, or just students and staff?

speaker: judyle
content: Ellen, great question. I'd say yes, parents too—especially since their views likely affect how comfortable kids feel at home. Do we have capacity to run a quick survey across all three groups?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: That sounds reasonable, Judi. Could we please send out a quick poll next week to see how fast we could get answers from all three groups?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Hi Jonno, I'm curious—are there already plans to conduct a student survey? Or is that something new we're proposing? Also, has anyone considered the impact of these surveys on our current risk assessment models?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Katrina, I think it's worth considering—wouldn't it be helpful to see if our current case rates align with what students actually report feeling? Probably not perfect, but better than nothing.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yeah, Dave, I guess my concern is making sure we're getting honest feedback. Are we asking them how they feel, or are we telling them what to feel?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Good point, Katrina. I think we need to make sure the survey asks open-ended questions—not leading ones. Would you mind helping us draft that, please?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Sure, I can help with that. I guess my bigger concern though is, when we talk about safety, especially for vulnerable populations, are we using metrics beyond just case counts?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I mean, I think we really need to look at cases among unvaccinated children. I'm wondering, Katina, did you have any numbers on that?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Not offhand, Kate. I don't think we've seen much data yet. I'll check.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Okay, so maybe we could look at that before we go forward with anything else.

speaker: judyle
content: I appreciate that, Kate. I do wonder—could we possibly get that breakdown within the next few days? I think having that clarity would help shape our thinking.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Judi, I’ll check with Health Services—can we pull that unvaccinated case rate for elementary students by Friday? Please let me know if you’ve got someone specific to reach out to.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Sounds good, Ellen. Will you please loop me in once you get that info?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Sorry, Jonno. I'm still trying to figure out if I can get that information. If not, I can try reaching out myself.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Please keep me posted, Katina.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I will.

speaker: davidoberg
content: I think we’re moving in the right direction here. Honestly, I’m hoping we can get that data soon—probably by Thursday would be ideal.

speaker: kateacuff
content: I mean, I'm certainly supportive of that. I was just saying earlier, if we had a survey, then we'd be able to sort of triangulate that data.

speaker: judyle
content: Kate, I agree—triangulating makes sense. But I do worry, will we even get enough responses to trust the results? Do we have a way to boost participation?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I don’t know, Judi. I mean, I think we could ask principals to put it up on their web pages and perhaps email it to students and staff.

speaker: judyle
content: That’s fair—but do we have bandwidth to manage that kind of rollout? I’d hate for it to fall through because no one’s tracking it.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote privately.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.1: Should the district require students to wear masks in classrooms during the school day?.  If each of you could please record your vote in the chat, I will tally them up and announce the results.

speaker: davidoberg
content: no

speaker: kateacuff
content: I don't think this is the time to mandate mask wearing in classrooms. There has been some evidence from other districts that masking may help reduce absenteeism due to illness. However, with the decline in cases, I am not sure it is necessary at this point. It is also difficult to enforce given the age range of our students.

speaker: judyle
content: yes

speaker: ellenosborne
content: abstain

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: My vote is yes. It seems like there's consensus among this group that we want to move forward with mask wearing in classrooms. And I think that's going to help us avoid any major outbreaks and disruptions to learning. So my vote is yes.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: yes

speaker: grahampaige
content: All right, thank you very much. I'll take all of those votes into consideration. And since there were no other motions or discussions at this time, Dr. Osborne, could you call us to order again so we can continue with our meeting? Thank you.
